title: Research the meaning of an ornament?
content:
Does anyone know of an online resource to research the origins / meanings of symbols or ornaments? I can’t seem to find a comprehensive resource.

 [‹ Who are the Rock Stars here?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/typophile.com/node/20583 "Go to previous forum topic") [Typophile Books is Back! ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/typophile.com/node/29975 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Alaskan

comments.content:
I just found a website that’s quite good, but, alas, the symbol I’m researching isn’t there.

[http://www.symbols.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/www.symbols.com/ "http://www.symbols.com")

Post a graphic of the symbol. Someone may be able to help.

ChrisL

Here’s a rough sketch of it:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634im_/http:/typophile.com/files/symbol_6413.jpg)
Looks like something Frutiger did for one of his books…

Might be related to the symbols for sun and sun cross...

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar\_symbol](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_symbol "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar\_symbol")

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun\_cross](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_cross "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun\_cross")

\> meanings of symbols or ornaments?

History?

This style is around 3084 B.C. — Porti

The divisions of a circle are by 4 in Egypt and early Crete; by 6 in Greece, Assyria, Syria, Italy.

But you need to be more specific with your search.

You may find that sometimes, an ornament is just an ornament.

It makes me think of shields. [Here is an image that looks somewhat similar.](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:Forngrekisk_sk%C3%B6ld%2C_Nordisk_familjebok.png)
Nobody did ask so far what is obviously to be asked first: Is ist an ornament or a sign? Where is it from? Without these tracks you’ll never know anything. –

It reminds me of the Hopi tribal symbol, or World Symbol.  
 [Here](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/www.mc.maricopa.edu/~ladelia/Music%20files/native_american/images/Hopi%20tribal%20symbol.jpg), and [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20071009211634/http:/www.whats-your-sign.com/images/NAWorldHopi.jpg).  
Which represents the world, with the four bars being north/east/south/west, the outermost points on the horizon where the sun passes through the year, the solstice/equinox points. The circles represent the “four nations, which came to the world to keep balance”.

But then again, your symbol might mean something else or nothing specific. :)

It’s embossed on a piece of silver jewelry, found on the street. Origin unknown - but it looks handmade.

All your suggestions are quite helpful; a few have come very close. Thanks!

AK

Work done on Silver may be a native American Indian symbol.

ChrisL

Heraldic symbol of the lesser known Uvula society (us).

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_  
Hiro

LOL! Now I am rteady for that tonsilectomy :-)

ChrisL
